newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal says yen bond cheaper than local finance.
newsitem.headline: Portugal says yen bond cheaper than local finance.

text.p: Portugal's Credit Institute opted to launch its 13 billion yen dual currency bond because it offered cheaper finance than the domestic market, its chairman said on Tuesday.

Vitor Bento, President of the Institute for Public Credit Management (IGCP), which sets the country's debt policy, said that he would continue to raise funds abroad whenever conditions were advantageous.
He told Reuters that the yen bond was a swap deal into escudos at an "all-in" cost of three-month Lisbor less 27 basis points. Lisbor was set at 5.84 percent on Tuesday.
The Institute's last issue of three-month Treasury bills on April 23 was made at an average 5.7037 percent.
"Whenever there is the possibility of raising finance (abroad) at a lower cost compared with internally, the IGCP will do it," Bento said.
The 13 billion yen dual currency bond, with a coupon of 5.36 percent, expires on May 15, 2000.
"The internal market displays spreads that are difficult to justify, the external market is the proof," he added.
Bento said that as the market risk of the operation was in escudos, it was neutral in terms of liquidity creation.
